pageContext.title: Looking for funding? Here are the 10 most active investors in India
pageContext.content:
India is on a roll: the number of investment deals in Indian startups increased from 216 in 2012 to 965 in 2016, according to CB Insights. And despite a dip in deal numbers in 2017, funding amounts rose by 48 percent, reaching a total of US$5.7 billion.

Apart from foreign investors, local venture capitalists are funding startups in India. Below is a list of the 10 most active Indian investors in 2018.

The data for this list was compiled from Tech in Asia‘s database, based on the number of investments these investors have made so far.

10. Artha India Ventures

Image courtesy Artha Ventures

Ashok Kumar Damani and Ramesh Damani, former directors of the Mumbai Stock Exchange, put up the firm in 2013 to fund early-stage and seed-round ventures.

Its diversified portfolio of more than 47 startups includes online interview platforms, cosmetic ecommerce, insurance companies, and classes aggregators.

AIV has made three investments in 2018: fashion app Coutloot, maternity and childcare platform BabyChakra, and quick-service restaurant startup Haazri.

9. Blume Ventures

Karthik Reddy, managing partner of Blume Ventures / Photo credit: Karthik Reddy

Blume invests in around 20 companies a year, particularly in seed-stage and early-stage ventures. Karthik Reddy and Sanjay Nath founded the firm in Mumbai in 2011 to fund companies in the analytics, consumer services, ecommerce, edtech, logistics, fintech, robotics, and travel categories.

The most notable of Blume’s 128 investments to date include food-delivery app Runnr and energy data analytics company Zenatix.

In 2018, it invested twice in Vokal, a peer-to-peer knowledge-sharing platform focused on various Indian languages. It also led funding rounds for US-based luxury vacations marketplace Rizort, video creation platform Rocketium, and healthtech company The Healthy Billion.

8. Brand Capital

Photo credit: Keresi72

Founded in 2005 by media firm Bennett Coleman and Co., Brand Capital has made 557 investments to date, according to Crunchbase.

The Mumbai-based investor participated in the US$1 billion debt financing of Airbnb in 2016 and Uber’s US$1 billion series E expansion round in 2015.

This year, Brand Capital has led at least four investments in India, including a US$3.5 million series D round for Homelane, an interior design and manufacturing provider. It has also poured money into the ecommerce, healthcare, deliveries, and financial industries.

7. IDG Ventures India

Photo credit: Myntra

IDG’s portfolio spans from startups to growth- and expansion-stage companies in a wide range of sectors.

The most successful of its 124 investments include ecommerce site Myntra, NewGen Software Technologies, and Fintellix Solutions.

The Bangalore-based venture capital (VC) firm has funded 11 companies so far in 2018. It led a US$1.9 million seed round for Kristal AI, co-led a US$3 million series A for HealthPlix, and co-led a US$2 million venture round into robotics startup Emotix.

6. Indian Angel Network

Photo credit: Alok MIttal

Founder Alok Mittal is known in India for his entrepreneurship, having established Indifi Technologies, a debt financing platform for small and medium-sized enterprises in India.

Today, his New Delhi-based VC has 75 investment rounds under its belt, including companies in healthtech, public transportation, content streaming, and software development.

Indian Angel Network led or co-led all six investments it has made so far in 2018. These include a US$3.6 million series A for biotech startup Pandorum Technologies and a US$400,000 seed round for fashion enterprise 6Degree.

5. Kae Capital

Photo credit: Sasha Mirchandani

Founder Sasha Mirchandani is a mainstay in India’s VC and entrepreneurship scene. He co-founded Mumbai Angels and previously managed the India operations of Blue Run Ventures. Prior to that, he founded Imercius Technologies, a healthcare-focused business process outsourcing firm.

Based in Mumbai, Kae Capital is sector agnostic and has made 57 investments since it was set up in 2010. It has participated in nine investment rounds this year so far, including a US$6.3 million venture round for LoanTap and a US$2.5 million series A round for knowledge-tech startup Disprz.

4. Kalaari Capital

Image courtesy Vani Kola

Kalaari is backed by a stellar team that includes co-founder Vani Kola, who was named as one of the most powerful women in Indian business in 2017 by Fortune India, and Ratan Tata, former chairman of Tata Sons, conglomerate Tata Group’s holding company.

Founded in Bangalore in 2011 with the aim of supporting early-stage companies, Kalaari has backed 126 investment rounds so far. In 2014, it participated in the US$134 million series D round for Snapdeal, an ecommerce company.

This year, Kalaari co-led one of its largest investments to date: a US$120 million series C round for CureFit, a digital health and fitness company.

Kalaari has also invested in the areas of knowledge sharing, insurance, fashion, and furniture, among others.

3. Matrix Partners India

Image courtesy Matrix Partners

In August 2018, Matrix Partners closed its third VC fund at US$300 million. The fund attracted from 43 investors and closed in less than three weeks.

The Mumbai-based firm’s track record includes 65 investments in recruitment, local search, buy and sell, healthtech, and rentals, among others. Its two most recent investments – both for undisclosed amounts – were in specialized startups: &Me, which uses Hindu medical system ayurveda to make food and beverage products for women, and lifestyle brand WomenOnSocial.

2. Microsoft ScaleUp

Image courtesy Microsoft

Innovators can take their big ideas to Microsoft ScaleUp, a restructured version of Microsoft Accelerator Bangalore operating under a bigger initiative called Microsoft for Startups. Microsoft ScaleUp has two verticals: venture capital and physical space.

Ever since its original inception in 2012, Microsoft ScaleUp program has made 121 investments. While it has yet to make an investment in 2018, it has a US$500 million fund to be used over the next two years.

1. Sequoia Capital India

Shailendra Singh (left), Sequoia Capital India’s managing director with David Corbin, director for content strategy at Tech in Asia Singapore 2016.

Based in Bengaluru, Sequoia Capital India has made 245 investments since it was set up in 2000.

It led or co-led more than half of those investments, including the July 2018 US$100 million series G round that propelled SaaS company Freshworks into unicorn status.

This year, Sequoia Capital India has bankrolled Indonesian fintech startup Moka, Malaysian deals platform [Fave](www.myfave.com], Indian shuttle service app Shuttl, and 21 other companies.
